The story of a deserted father forms one of a series of films created originally for day-time television panel discussions to introduce to the public the range of social services available from Government and other agencies.

results.title: Joan (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Department of Social Security and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Security”.
One of a series of films created originally for day-time television panel discussions to introduce to the public the range of social services available from Government and other agencies. This program deals with the problems of unmarried mothers and in particular, with Joan, who worked at an assortment of jobs in order to keep her daughter. The film looks back at her life and at how she and her daughter have come through difficult years. It also highlights a social welfare organisation known as CHUM - Care and Help for Unmarried Mothers.

results.title: Jane
results.creator_credit: P. Robinson, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Security”.
Tells about a young country girl who moved to the city when she was nineteen years old. Describes how, although unhappy in the city, she is determined to stay until she conquers her restlessness and loneliness and finds employment. One of a series of films created originally for day-time television panel discussions to introduce to the public the range of social services available from Government and other agencies.

results.title: Hattie
results.creator_credit: Debby Kingsland, Suzanne Barker, Dept of Social Security and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Security”.
Hattie is seventy-six and completely alone, she has lost contact with a of her old friends and interests and feels that her life is now totally empty. Although she has always been happy and active, Hattie says she doesn’t care if she dies tomorrow, and that there are a lot of people like her, discarded because they are old. One of a series of films created originally for day- time television panel discussions to introduce to the public the range of social services available from Government and other agencies.

results.title: The Cruickshank family
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Suzanne Parker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Security”.
This film deals with the problems faced by the Cruickshank family living on the land - insecure employment, lack of constant medical benefits cover, and the need to continue in unpredictable work in a rural environment. They are aware of their own powerlessness against accident, sickness, and the economic forces governing their lives and they can only hope for the best.

results.title: You don't fool me
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows how a social psychological experiment is designed, conducted and analysed. The experiment is a test to see if non-verbal behaviour gives clues as to whether a person is being deceptive - the hypothesis being that the face will not give clues to deception, but the hands and feet will. One of a series of a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science Open University. The purpose is to provide insight into social behaviour and experience. The essential focus is on theories, findings, and methods of social psychology.

results.title: Analysing interaction No.1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Nell Smith, BBC and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows an interaction sequence between a young man (Russ) and an older woman (Angela) who meet at a party. This sequence is then analysed by seven different psychologists and sociologists who adapt different orientations. Three of the analyses are presented in the first part. Suitable for Mid-Upper Secondary School level.

results.title: Understanding aggro/hooliganism
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Research into the origins and forms of soccer hooliganism. It is a vehicle for the younger generation to find excitement, including ritualised violence. Presented by Dr George Gaskell.
